Comments_List: I feel that, with the knowledge I gained by taking Italian 110, I could manage to have a conversation in Italian (without using several verb tenses that we haven't learned yet, of course).
Learned how to utilize the Italian language to represent thoughts ranging from present to past actions. Learned much more than expected.

One really great thing about my section was that there were only 9 people, so there were more opportunities for speaking and engagement with our instructor. However, I know that not all sections are like that, but I feel like the course would improve if there were a limit on class size. Also, please stop asking us if we prefer the mountains or the sea (the sea is the clear winner here).
It is an extremely fun and interactive course that I got so much out of. It pushes you but you never feel uncomfortable because everyone else is in the same boat. I loved it.

Strengths: Phenomenal professor, great class size, engaging material.

Weaknesses: Terrible textbook

Italian is a great language to take at Yale. Many high schools don't offer it, but a background in Spanish or French is very helpful and makes it easier to face the challenge of learning a new language. The department is large enough and can offer enough sections that there is flexibility when scheduling classes, but it isn't so large that you're unable to participate in class or that everyone you know is taking it.
Absolutely. As someone who has trouble learning languages, this was an excellent course.
I would recommend the professor course combo. The course should only be taken by those with an interest in the language as it is a somewhat difficult course.
